As an example, **the 8Base group’s victimology (mostly SMBs) demonstrates that many new actors aggressively pursue smaller businesses** ([www.helpnetsecurity.com](https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/02/11/8base-ransomware-group-leaders-arrested-leak-site-seized-phobos/#:~:text=The%20Phobos%20%E2%80%93%208Base%20connection)) ([www.helpnetsecurity.com](https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2025/02/11/8base-ransomware-group-leaders-arrested-leak-site-seized-phobos/#:~:text=match%20at%20L56%20%E2%80%9CTaking%20advantage,data%20but%20also%20threatening%20to)), not just Fortune 500 firms.

- **Geo-Political Targeting:** Some targeting reflects geopolitical motives or convenience. **Russian-speaking gangs continue to avoid hitting Russia or CIS countries**, presumably to stay in good favor locally – this didn’t change with new groups (their leak sites remained void of Russian companies). Meanwhile, **state-affiliated actors like those deploying Warlock chose targets of strategic interest (which included government agencies)**, blurring if the motive was purely financial or partly espionage ([www.bleepingcomputer.com](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-sharepoint-servers-also-targeted-in-ransomware-attacks/#:~:text=Microsoft%20Threat%20Intelligence%20researchers%20have,49704%20vulnerabilities)). Also, in the Israel-Hamas war flare (late 2023), *hacktivist ransomware* emerged (e.g. “SiegedSec” and others) that attacked entities in Israel or supportive countries with ransom demands more as political statements. This trend continued with some politically motivated data leaks in 2025, though they were a minority compared to financially driven attacks.

In summary, **emerging ransomware actors largely follow the money – targeting U.S. and Western European organizations, especially in manufacturing, tech/services, and other critical industries**. The data confirms heavy targeting of those regions (with the U.S. a victim in **67% of cases in Q2 2025 ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=The%20US%20remains%20the%20most,is%20exploiting%20vulnerabilities%20in%20German))**). However, fragmentation has meant **a wider distribution of attacks across sectors and some expansion into new geographies**. No sector can consider itself “safe,” and even countries with fewer past incidents (like in Asia or the Middle East) saw high-profile victims due to the opportunism of these new groups. 

**Analyst Note:** For defenders, this means focusing defenses not just on the traditionally targeted verticals, but assuming that *any critical business function* could be a ransomware target. The fact that manufacturing and professional services remain top targets suggests adversaries favor organizations with *both* high downtime costs and capability to pay – a combination found in many industries. The rise of attacks on German firms by SafePay ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=resources%20and%20stringent%20cybersecurity%20regulations%2C,incentives%20and%20high%20ransom%20payout)) or on Japanese firms by groups like NightSpire ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=,education%2C%20manufacturing%2C%20government%2C%20retail%2C%C2%A0logistics%2C%20etc)) are case studies in how one group’s campaign can skew victim stats. Tracking these trends requires continuous threat intelligence, as **the most targeted sectors can shift quarter by quarter based on a single group’s focus ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=As%20is%20now%20standard%2C%20manufacturing,can%20dramatically%20shape%20ransomware%20trends))** (e.g., Clop’s Cleo exploit spree making retail spike, then fading). Overall, emerging actors are casting a wider net, even as they concentrate on lucrative targets.

## Adapting Tactics: Evasion and Extortion Innovations

With cybersecurity defenses improving, ransomware actors have **sharpened their tactics to bypass protections and increase leverage over victims**. Since 2025, both new and established groups have shown notable adaptations in their techniques:

- **Advanced EDR Evasion and “Defense Neutralization”:** Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tools and modern anti-malware make traditional ransomware binaries easier to detect. Attackers responded by integrating **EDR-killer capabilities** into their playbooks. Many groups now use the **“Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver” (BYOVD)** technique: they drop an older, signed driver known to have exploitable privileges and use it to disable security software. For example, *The Gentlemen* ransomware was observed using a tool (`Allpatch2.exe`) that exploits **ThrottleStop’s vulnerable driver (ThrottleStop.sys)** to kill processes of antivirus and EDR tools ([ransomnews.online](https://ransomnews.online/hub/ransomnews-thegentlemen.html#:~:text=HUB%20%40%20ransomNews%20,Remote%20access%3A%20AnyDesk%2C%20compromised%20RDP)). Similarly, older gangs like BlackByte and AvosLocker had used the vulnerable **RTCore64 driver** in past attacks – these methods are now widespread among emerging actors. Attackers also leverage scripting (PowerShell, batch files) to turn off Windows Defender, uninstall backup agents, and clear logs as part of the ransomware execution routine. **Living-off-the-land** techniques – e.g., using legit admin binaries like `wmic`, `netsh`, or PowerShell – help criminals blend into normal operations while they prepare the encryption bomb.

- **Shorter Attack Timelines & Avoidance of Detection:** Ransomware dwell time within networks has decreased in many cases – some groups strike within *hours or a couple days* of initial breach, giving defenders a very small window to respond. This “speed run” approach is facilitated by automated tools and scripts. For instance, after infiltrating a network (often via stolen credentials or a vulnerability), attackers may run batch scripts to deploy ransomware to hundreds of machines at once (through domain Group Policy or PsExec) ([www.bleepingcomputer.com](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-sharepoint-servers-also-targeted-in-ransomware-attacks/#:~:text=They%20then%20move%20laterally%20with,Warlock%20ransomware%20across%20compromised%20systems)). By simultaneously encrypting many systems, they aim to **overwhelm EDR/quarantine capabilities**. Additionally, almost all modern ransomware is now **packed or obfuscated** to evade static detection. Many are written in less common languages like **Golang, Rust, or Nim**, which produce binaries that generic scanners have a harder time parsing. DireWolf’s Golang malware and DevMan’s switch from C++ to Rust are cases in point, reflecting a wider trend of attackers adopting languages that pose analysis challenges ([www.halcyon.ai](https://www.halcyon.ai/threat-group/dire-wolf#:~:text=First%20appearing%20May%202025%2C%20this,Curve25519%20and%20ChaCha20%20encryption%20from)) ([www.halcyon.ai](https://www.halcyon.ai/threat-group/devman#:~:text=Operational%20Complexity%20%20,wide%20distribution)). Some groups even employ custom “cryptors” – wrapper software to encrypt and morph the ransomware payload anew for each attack, to avoid signature-based detection.

- **Targeted Exploitation of Known Vulnerabilities:** Rather than rely exclusively on phishing or RDP brute force (though those continue), many groups shifted to **exploit publicly known vulnerabilities in internet-facing systems** as a quick path in. The year 2025 saw multiple campaigns built on this: e.g., **Clop ransomware massively exploited zero-days in file transfer software (MOVEit, GoAnywhere, and later Cleo platform) to breach dozens of organizations in one sweep ([www.neteye-blog.com](https://www.neteye-blog.com/2026/01/ransomware-double-extortion-attack-2025-overview/#:~:text=Image))**. Emerging groups learned from this – **Qilin and Akira** (two rising RaaS in 2024–25) were noted to rely on *mass exploitation of vulnerabilities* for initial access ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=,compared%20to%20the%20previous%20quarter)). By using readily available exploits (sometimes straight from proof-of-concept code on GitHub), they can compromise many targets quickly without the uncertainty of phishing. In fact, analysts predict the “next generation” of ransomware leaders will succeed by **“combining automated discovery tools with public proof-of-concept exploits” to speed up compromises ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=and%20precision))**. The Warlock case – exploiting SharePoint 0-days – is an extreme example of using exploits *not just after they’re public, but even as 0-day*, demonstrating the upper end of technical capability in some threat actors ([www.bleepingcomputer.com](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-sharepoint-servers-also-targeted-in-ransomware-attacks/#:~:text=attacks%20www,vulnerable%20to%20widespread%20attacks%20targeting)). Improved patch management by organizations can blunt this, but as long as unpatched systems persist, ransomware crews will weaponize those CVEs for quick wins.

- **Multi-Stage and Covert Operations:** Many emerging groups conduct intrusions that resemble **espionage actors** until the final step. They quietly **exfiltrate large volumes of data** (often over days), use covert backdoors, and establish persistence before detonating ransomware. Sinobi’s “enterprise-aware” style – ensuring they have full domain control and data in hand before encryption ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=Sinobi%C2%A0appears%20to%C2%A0operate%C2%A0as%20either%20a%20rebrand,prioritizing%20operational%20control%20before%20monetization)) ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=reverse%20engineering%20%2F%20attribution%20comparison%29)) – is reflective of this. Some groups deploy **Cobalt Strike beacons or other post-exploitation frameworks** long before deploying ransomware, indicating a period of reconnaissance. This approach counters improved defenses by delaying noisy ransomware actions until the last possible moment, when it’s too late for the victim to respond. It’s also a hedge: if something goes awry, the intruder can still profit by selling or extorting the stolen data without ever launching the encryptor.

- **Extortion Beyond “Double”:** To increase pressure on victims, threat actors have expanded their extortion toolset beyond just encryption (locking files) and data leaks. This **“multi-pronged extortion” or even “triple extortion”** trend includes:
  - **DDoS Attacks:** Several groups now threaten or carry out **Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks** on a victim’s public websites or infrastructure during negotiations ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/ransomware-gangs-are-now-expanding-to-physical-threats-in-the-real-world#:~:text=Denial%20of%20Service%20,choice%20situation%2C%20we)). By taking down the company’s customer-facing services (on top of having their internal data encrypted), attackers apply extra leverage. For example, if a retailer’s website is offline due to DDoS, revenue loss piles on top of the ransomware incident, pressuring the victim to settle quickly. This tactic was observed as early as 2020 (e.g., SunCrypt, RagnarLocker did it), but became more mainstream by 2025. Reports note some ransom groups explicitly offer “DDoS as a service” add-ons to affiliates. TechRadar in late 2025 highlighted that **criminals pair file encryption with DDoS attacks on the front-end, “bringing the entire business to a screeching halt”** in certain cases ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/ransomware-gangs-are-now-expanding-to-physical-threats-in-the-real-world#:~:text=Denial%20of%20Service%20,choice%20situation%2C%20we)).
  
  - **Harassing Phone Calls and Emails:** Ransom gangs also started **personally contacting employees and executives** of victim organizations. This can include emails to the board or CEO, or phone calls where hackers directly deliver threats. By informing individuals (and sometimes clients or partners of the victim) about the breach, they create internal pressure on the leadership to resolve the situation. There have been cases of attackers **calling a company’s help desk or CEO** to taunt them that their network is locked – a psychological tactic. The TechRadar piece mentioned that these phone call harassment methods were seen in a couple of cases ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/ransomware-gangs-are-now-expanding-to-physical-threats-in-the-real-world#:~:text=Denial%20of%20Service%20,choice%20situation%2C%20we)).
  
  - **Threats of Physical Harm:** In 2025 an alarming statistic emerged from a Semperis security study: **around 46% of U.S. companies that experienced ransomware reported that the attackers threatened physical violence against executives if the ransom wasn’t paid** ([ridgemarkinsurance.com](https://ridgemarkinsurance.com/ransomware-escalates-physical-threats-against-company-leaders/#:~:text=Ransomware%20Escalates%3A%20Physical%20Threats%20Against,were%20physically%20threatened%20if%20their)). These threats are usually delivered via anonymous emails or messages as part of the extortion. For example, a hacker might say *“We know where your CEO lives”* or insinuate they could send someone to their house. While these are almost certainly empty threats (no confirmed cases of cybercriminals acting on them physically), they represent a new **extreme intimidation tactic**. It shows how far ransomware gangs will go to instill fear. As one survey noted in mid-2025, *“in 40%+ of incidents, CEOs or execs were directly threatened with physical harm”* by the attackers ([ridgemarkinsurance.com](https://ridgemarkinsurance.com/ransomware-escalates-physical-threats-against-company-leaders/#:~:text=Ransomware%20Escalates%3A%20Physical%20Threats%20Against,were%20physically%20threatened%20if%20their)). This is effectively **taking extortion into the real world**, adding a terrifying dimension for victims even if it’s just bluster.
  
  - **Targeting Customers/Partners:** Another extension has been contacting the victim’s clients or business partners to inform them their data was stolen, attempting to force the victim’s hand via reputational damage. Some gangs set up fake Twitter accounts or dark web pages to leak tidbits of data to media. By involving third parties (customers, regulators, press), they increase the fallout for the victim beyond the immediate IT impact.
  
  - **Ransomware + Data Theft *Without* Ransom Demand:** A curious twist observed with a group called **MalasLocker (mid-2023)**, which carried into 2025 discussions: they would encrypt data but instead of a traditional ransom, they demanded the victim **donate to a charity** and show proof of donation to get the decryptor. While not widespread, this Robin Hood-esque stance complicates the landscape (malicious nonetheless, but different motive claims). It didn’t persist widely, but it’s worth noting as an experiment in extortion model – perhaps an attempt to morally justify the crime or confuse law enforcement tracking payments. No major 2025 group copied this approach (most still want direct payment), but it exemplifies the **continual experimentation with extortion methods**.

- **Adaptations to Security Improvements:** As defenders improve backups and incident response, attackers adapt by **seeking out backup systems to delete or encrypt** (targeting shadow copies, NAS backups, cloud backup credentials, etc.). Most ransom notes now specifically mention if backups are found, they’ll be destroyed or already have been. Attackers also monitor response actions in real-time; for instance, some ransomware will detect if it’s running in a sandbox or being debugged and behave benignly to avoid analysis. Others generate unique encryption keys per victim and communicate with command servers so that simply obtaining the binary doesn’t allow decryption for others – a response to earlier incidents where law enforcement shared keys. In general, **ransomware code quality has improved** among top groups, making accidental errors (that allow free decryption) rarer.

- **Focus on Privilege and Identity Abuse:** Recognizing that multifactor authentication and improved identity security were blunting some attacks, ransomware intruders began ***bypassing MFA via social engineering or using MFA fatigue techniques*** (bombarding a user with push notifications). Groups like Scattered Spider, known for such tactics, hint at incorporating this into RaaS offerings ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/threat-spotlight-ransomware-and-cyber-extortion-in-q3-2025/#:~:text=,Against%20Scattered%20Spider)). Once inside, they seek Domain Admin privileges rapidly (for example, by exploiting Active Directory flaws or using credential dumping tools). **Use of legitimate admin tools** (like the built-in `ntdsutil` to extract AD data, or leveraging systems management software the victim uses) has grown. This lowers their footprint and often evades detection by appearing as normal admin activity.

**Summary of Tactical Trends:** By late 2025, ransomware actors behave more like full-spectrum adversaries: they combine stealth (to evade EDR), speed (to outpace response), and **multi-dimensional extortion** (to leave victims with no good options). Confirmed shifts include **extortion-only attacks gaining popularity ([flashpoint.io](https://flashpoint.io/blog/new-ransomware-as-a-service-raas-groups-to-watch-in-2025/#:~:text=1))**, although pure data-theft attacks often evolve into encryption as well (as the NightSpire case proved) ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=NightSpire%C2%A0is%20notable%20for%20its%20evolution,site%20exposure)) ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=%2A%20Observed%20evolution%20from%20exfiltration,in%20later%202025%20activity)). Meanwhile, **double extortion is “business as usual”** and even triple extortion (encrypt + leak + DDoS) is increasingly reported ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/ransomware-gangs-are-now-expanding-to-physical-threats-in-the-real-world#:~:text=Denial%20of%20Service%20,choice%20situation%2C%20we)). Threat actors also tailor their techniques to the environment: if a victim has strong backups, they emphasize data leaks and other pressure; if the victim has sensitive life-or-death operations (like a hospital), they exploit that urgency in negotiations (despite any ethical qualms, as seen when some gangs reneged on healthcare exemptions).

From an analyst perspective, these adaptations show an **ongoing cat-and-mouse game between ransomware gangs and defenders**. Every defensive improvement (better EDR, widespread MFA, faster incident response) is met with an offensive adjustment (driver exploits, social engineering of MFA, faster deployment of ransomware, etc.). Notably, the willingness to use psychological and physical intimidation in 2025 is an escalation beyond the technical realm, indicating that top-tier cybercriminals are **resorting to mafia-like tactics** to secure payment ([ridgemarkinsurance.com](https://ridgemarkinsurance.com/ransomware-escalates-physical-threats-against-company-leaders/#:~:text=Ransomware%20Escalates%3A%20Physical%20Threats%20Against,were%20physically%20threatened%20if%20their)) ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/ransomware-gangs-are-now-expanding-to-physical-threats-in-the-real-world#:~:text=Denial%20of%20Service%20,choice%20situation%2C%20we)). This is a worrying trend that could attract even greater law enforcement attention, but also could scare victims into compliance.

---

**Conclusion:** The late-2025 to early-2026 ransomware landscape is one of **highly active, dynamic threat actors who are often new in name but not necessarily new in experience**. Emerging groups have quickly stepped into the void left by disrupted gangs, bringing with them **sophisticated tactics, cross-platform capabilities, and aggressive extortion techniques**. The **RaaS economy’s evolution** – toward fragmentation, affiliate-hopping, and innovation in criminal business models – has made the ecosystem more resilient to crackdowns. Law enforcement operations, while increasing in frequency and global coordination, have so far only modestly hindered the overall volume of attacks ([www.techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/pro/security/takedowns-and-arrests-didnt-slow-down-ransomware-in-2025#:~:text=2026,victims%20rose%20from%20approximately%205%2C400)). The ransomware actors’ behavior (rebranding, shifting infrastructure, and upping the ante on victims) shows a threat that is adaptive and not easily deterred.

Going into 2026, organizations face a **plurality of ransomware threats** rather than a few big names. Many of these groups share similar techniques (thanks to common tutelage or leaked code) – meaning even smaller actors can cause **“enterprise-grade” damage ([cyble.com](https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/10-new-ransomware-groups-of-2025-threat-trend-2026/#:~:text=Even%20as%20global%20law%20enforcement,grade%20efficiency))**. Key sectors like manufacturing, tech, and critical services remain hot targets, especially in the U.S. and Europe ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=The%20US%20remains%20the%20most,is%20exploiting%20vulnerabilities%20in%20German)) ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/ransomware-cyber-extortion-threat-intel-q2-2025/#:~:text=As%20is%20now%20standard%2C%20manufacturing,can%20dramatically%20shape%20ransomware%20trends)), but no sector or region is truly safe given the opportunism arising from the ransomware fragmentation ([reliaquest.com](https://reliaquest.com/blog/threat-spotlight-ransomware-and-cyber-extortion-in-q3-2025/#:~:text=,and%20regions%20not%20traditionally%20targeted)). 

On the defensive side, knowing the **profiles and tactics of these emerging groups** is crucial for risk assessment. For instance, recognizing that a group like Gentlemen might already have domain-wide persistence means responders must check Group Policy and admin tool logs; understanding that a gang like SafePay favors certain regions can inform threat hunting in those locales. Effective defense in this era requires not just patching and backing up, but also **anticipating the extortion playbook** – from DDoS to doxxing – that might be used against an organization.

In summary, the modern ransomware threat actor landscape is characterized by **rapid adaptation, a proliferation of new actors (often built on old bones), and an expansion of criminal tactics beyond the purely technical**. While confirmed intelligence gives us profiles of groups like DevMan, Nova, Sinobi, and The Gentlemen – each with unique traits – they collectively indicate where ransomware is heading: **more diffuse, arguably more dangerous, and deeply embedded in an ongoing arms race with defenders**. Continued tracking of these actors and collaboration across law enforcement and industry will be needed to turn the tide, as thus far the ecosystem has proven it can **survive and evolve in spite of considerable pressure** ([www.cybernewscentre.com](https://www.cybernewscentre.com/5th-august-2025-cyber-update-global-blacksuit-ransomware-takedown/#:~:text=The%20operation%27s%20success%20in%20disrupting,criminal%20reorganization%20under%20new%20banners)).
